0.text:
Translator: Ivana Krivokuća
Reviewer: Denise RQ

7.text:
This photo is of someone
that I went to university with here at UQ.

14.text:
and she became famous
for writing this novel,

18.text:
which went on to win
Australia's number one literary award.

21.text:
Helen said that novel was based
on conversations she'd had

26.text:
with her Ukrainian militants
about their experiences in World War II.

29.text:
Helen made quite a big deal
about her Ukrainian heritage.

33.text:
She'd go to multicultural festivals
in traditional dress,

36.text:
do Ukrainian dances.
and sing Ukrainian songs. etc.

40.text: What was extraordinary about this story

42.text:
was that a couple of years
after the book got released,

45.text:
it became apparent that Helen Demidenko
was in fact Helen Darville.

51.text:
and in fact she just completely fabricated
her entire ethnic heritage.

58.text:
she became the latest in a long
and scandalous list of imposters,

62.text:
people who have faked who they are
in order to get some kind of advantage.

66.text: History is full of these people:

69.text: women who've tried to pass as men,

72.text:
paupers who have tried to pass
as members of the royal family,

76.text:
and also people who have tried
to fake their race.

79.text: It could be that you're old enough now

81.text:
to be able to reflect
on a time in your life

83.text:
where maybe you've just stretched
the truth a little bit about your past,

87.text:
where you've allowed someone to think
that you're someone that you're not.

90.text: If that has happened to you,

92.text:
you might want to just think
about that moment for a while,

95.text:
while I make three very quick points
about imposters.

98.text:
The first thing that I want to mention
was that a lot of imposters

102.text:
seem to be able to get away with their lie
for an extraordinary period of time,

108.text:
despite what seems at times
to be a smoking gun evidence

116.text:
before she started faking
her Ukrainian heritage.

119.text:
Among people who knew of her,
including myself,

122.text:
it was the cause of quite a bit
of puzzlement and discussion

125.text:
that this person suddenly had
a different name

128.text:
and suddenly had this never
before detected Ukrainian heritage.

131.text:
There must have been
literally hundreds of people

134.text:
All personally knew
her very British parents,

137.text:
and yet it took two years
before that lie got exposed.

144.text:
An extraordinary example
of imposter blindness

147.text:
relates to the strange case
of Billy Tipton.

149.text:
Billy Tipton was a very talented
and successful jazz musician

157.text:
It was only after he died that people
found out that he was in fact a she.

161.text:
This is despite the fact, mind you,
that she had four wives,

166.text:
None of whom suspected
that they're in fact married to a woman.

171.text:
Billy went to extraordinary lengths
to protect her secret.

174.text:
She said that she had
this terrible accident

178.text:
and that helped to explain
the need for the bandages

181.text: around the chest all the time,

182.text:
and it helped to explain
the need for a prosthetic penis.

185.text:
But all the same, this is
an incredibly exposable secret.

188.text:
How could you get away with a lie
of that magnitude for your entire life?

192.text:
Probably my favorite example
of imposter blindness

196.text: relates to this woman, Hannah Snell.

198.text:
Hannah was a sailor and a soldier
in the British Navy in the 19th century.

204.text:
For most of her time,
for about four or five years,

207.text: she masqueraded as a man, James Gray.

209.text:
And there was this dramatic anecdote
where at one point she'd been caught

213.text:
drinking and rabble-rousing
with mates on this naval ship,

216.text:
and as punishment,
she got sentenced to the lash.

219.text:
And of course, the lash
is delivered to a bare back.

222.text:
Afterwards, the captain
of the ship wrote in his log

226.text:
about the strange breast-like shapes
on this man's chest,

229.text:
and yet, still the paint
didn't drop, right?

233.text:
Presumably, it just lays so far outside
the realm of this guy's imagination

237.text:
that a soldier in the British Navy
could possibly be a woman,

241.text:
that he couldn't trust
what he was seeing with his own eyes.

246.text:
imposter blindness speaks to a rather
charming aspect of modern society.

252.text:
Despite our self-image just being
really quite cynical and skeptical,

257.text:
that other people are
who they say they are.

263.text:
"It doesn't occur to us to ask
whether that masked figure

266.text:
poised over our naked unconscious body
with a knife is in fact a doctor."

270.text:
Just says that probably
hasn't occurred to you to question

272.text:
that I am in fact an academic
at the University of Queensland.

276.text: We tend to trust these things implicitly.

283.text:
Now I want to talk
about the motives for impostorism.

289.text:
Not all imposters are motivated
for fame or fortune, like Helen Demidenko.

293.text:
Some imposters are escapologists -
they're running away from a flawed past,

297.text:
and they're trying
to rehabilitate their image

300.text: and atone context of a great shame.

302.text:
Some imposters
are just rampant adventurers.

305.text:
They're really just getting off
on the thrill of living in the world

309.text:
where there's literally no obstacles
to being whoever you want to be.

312.text:
Some imposters, I think,
are attracted to the idea

315.text:
of being part of a close-knit community
that offers solidarity and offers support,

321.text:
and perhaps gives you a touch of sympathy
from the outside world.

325.text:
So that might help to explain
the vast number of people

328.text:
who lay false claims to being
Vietnam War veterans, for example,

334.text:
But some imposters
are running away from persecution.

340.text:
very dramatic and inventive
forms of impostorism.

343.text:
There are examples, for example,
of Jewish people in World War II

347.text:
who would disguise
or literally change their physiology

352.text:
to be able to escape
detection from the Nazis.

354.text:
But quite often in life,
if you want to run away from persecution,

357.text:
you don't have to do anything
quite as dramatic as that.

361.text:
If you're gay, for example,
to not reveal your sexuality

365.text:
is frequently enough
to pass as being straight.

368.text:
So the gay person who is closeted
can find themselves

372.text: living the life of an imposter

373.text:
not because of what they've said,
not because of what they've done,

378.text:
but because of what they haven't said
and what they haven't done.

382.text:
This can have a peculiar set
of psychological consequences.

387.text:
There was a great study
done by Deborrah Frable and others

391.text:
where she tracked
all these undergraduate students

394.text:
at Harvard University
for a couple of weeks.

397.text:
Some of these students
had mild stigmas that were visible.

404.text:
They're conspicuous,
so maybe they're physically disabled

407.text:
or they're stutterers,
or they're very obese,

409.text:
or they're members of racial minorities
like African-Americans.

412.text:
Others had mild stigmas
that were concealable, invisible:

417.text:
people with eating disorders,
people who are gay,

420.text:
people who came
from very poor backgrounds.

422.text:
You might expect that people
who have concealable stigmas,

427.text:
who can pass quite easily
to the mainstream,

430.text:
should fare better in this new context,
but in fact, the reverse was true.

435.text:
It was the people
who had the invisible stigmas,

438.text:
who had the opportunity
of living a double life,

443.text:
in terms of well-being,
in terms of self-esteem, etc.

446.text:
This dovetails
with a whole lot of research

448.text:
that suggested to live the double life
is a long, lonely, and difficult path.

453.text:
To be forced to be out and proud
about your situation

458.text: but what it does give you

460.text:
is the opportunity
to live an integrated life,

463.text:
and also it gives other people who are
like you the opportunity to find you;

467.text:
and those people who are like you
become this incredibly important source

471.text:
of self-esteem, social support,
and well-being.

476.text:
Another point I want to make is
that even when imposters are rogues,

482.text: even when they're scoundrels or criminals,

486.text:
society often holds a degree
of admiration for them.

489.text: This is fond fascination for the imposter.

491.text:
There are dozens of films
that have been built

497.text: and in many of these films,

498.text:
the imposter is portrayed
as the hero or as a semi-hero.

503.text:
And in some ways,
that's not entirely surprising.

506.text:
We live in a world where often there are
obstacles to social mobility,

510.text:
and then you see these people
who take this crazy risk

513.text:
to catapult themselves
into the social world

522.text:
Imposters can also be attractive
in the way that they highlight

526.text:
the vanities, the pretensions,
and the prejudices

530.text: of the society in which we live.

532.text:
We do live in a world
which is overly impressed

536.text:
by superficial characteristics
like your title or your uniform.

542.text:
to see someone
take rampant advantage of that.

544.text:
My favorite example of this
is the so-called Captain of Köpenick.

549.text:
The Captain of Köpenick
was in fact this man, Wilhelm Voigt.

553.text: He was a very poor cobbler in Berlin,

557.text:
and he was a petty thief
who has spent half of his life in jail.

560.text:
But his life turned around
when he found in a second hand store

563.text:
the discarded uniform
of a captain in the Prussian Guards.

568.text:
Of course, he discovered
that once he wore this uniform,

572.text:
people in the street
would snap to attention,

575.text:
and that automatically,
offer him the kind of respect

579.text:
Emboldened by this,
he hatched what probably remains,

583.text:
I think, one of the ballsiest
criminal conspiracies of all time,

586.text:
where he put on this uniform,
he went to a local army barracks,

591.text:
he barked orders
at these soldiers in the barracks,

595.text:
and formed a little squad
of about a dozen soldiers

598.text:
who he led to believe, "We're going to go
on this very important mission."

602.text:
He marched the soldiers
down to the local railway station,

605.text:
and they traveled all the way to Köpenick,
which is a town just outside Berlin.

611.text:
they dramatically confronted
the mayor of the town and the treasurer

614.text:
and arrested them on completely
fabricated charges of embezzlement;

619.text:
and these two people who,
were presumably completely bewildered,

623.text:
were then taken on the train
back to Berlin to face interrogation.

627.text:
Wilhelm Voigt was able to go home,
presumably laughing his head off.

631.text:
What he'd done is eventually confiscated
4,000 marks as part of the trial,

637.text:
and then he was able to enjoy
his newfound wealth.

639.text:
Unfortunately, Wilhelm was arrested,
and he was thrown in jail,

645.text: but he was released quite early,

648.text:
and he ended up becoming
a German folk hero,

653.text: But I don't want to give the impression

655.text:
that imposters are always seen
to be romantic or attractive.

659.text:
Research by Jolanda Jetten and myself
her at UQ suggest

662.text: that if you are member of the group

664.text:
that somebody is making
a false claim to belong to,

666.text:
then you typically don't find
these kinds of acts

669.text:
particularly romantic,
or attractive, or funny.

671.text: The more you care about your group,

673.text:
the less likely you are to find
the positive side of impostorism.

677.text:
The reason genuine members of the group
are highly threatened by imposters

683.text:
is really rooted very deeply
in the psychology of group membership.

688.text:
People want their groups to be tight,
cohesive, and well-defined,

694.text:
and to have clear boundaries;
these are the good things for us.

700.text:
They make a mockery
over the criterion for acceptance,

703.text:
and they completely dilute
the boundaries of the group

706.text:
and dilute what it means
to be a member of that group.

709.text: So, if you're a genuine member of a group,

711.text:
an imposter is like an irritant
or a contaminant

714.text:
that's entered the skin of the group,
and you're desperate to get rid of it.

717.text:
Sometimes, that desperation
can reach a fever pitch,

722.text:
and it can border on being
something like a witch hunt,

726.text:
about who's a real group member
and who is a fake.

729.text:
So, can you call yourself a Christian
if you don't go to church a hell of a lot?

734.text:
Can you call yourself a vegetarian
if you occasionally eat seafood?

738.text:
Some people would say yes,
and some people would say no.

742.text:
Of course, there are
no objective answers to these questions.

747.text:
and that debate is wrapped
in emotion, politics, and ideology.

751.text:
If it comes to this tense struggle
to work out

754.text:
what the non-negotiable norms
of the group are,

757.text:
and sometimes,
the accusation of impostorism

759.text:
really becomes a way
of slapping people into line

762.text:
when you feel as if they are straying
from the path.

764.text:
We have a whole bunch of terms
in the English language

767.text:
to describe people
who have what you see to be

770.text:
a superficial claim
to a particular identity,

773.text:
but deep down, you suspect
they're not the real deal.

776.text:
Most of these terms are
incredibly high charged and derogatory,

780.text:
so here, we're talking
about impostorism as an accusation,

788.text:
impostorism as an instrument of control
or even as a form of bullying.

794.text:
I've spoken about extraordinary people
who've acted as imposters,

798.text:
we've spoken about impostorism
as an accusation.

802.text:
I just want to spend
a few minutes at the end

804.text: talking about impostorism as an anxiety.

807.text: These two psychologists back in the 1970s

811.text:
detected what they termed
the imposter phenomenon.

815.text:
They found out that there was
a hell of a lot of people in the workplace

821.text: that their public reputations far exceeded

825.text:
what they believed
their true talents to be.

828.text:
These psychologists originally thought
this is something quite specific

832.text:
to the psychology
of that first generation of women

835.text:
who went into professional life
in the 60s and 70s.

838.text:
But we now know
that it's equally true of men,

840.text:
and it's completely rife in universities,
both among students and staff.

845.text:
Many of these people who suffer
from the imposter syndrome

848.text:
are very successful people,
but they can't internalize this success.

852.text:
They attribute their success
to things other than their talents -

856.text:
to contacts, to perseverance,
to timing, to luck.

862.text:
These people live lives that are
constantly on a brink of a great shame.

867.text: They feel as any day now

869.text:
they're going to get tapped
on the shoulder by someone,

872.text:
and someone will pull back
the curtain - Wizard of Oz style -

876.text:
as the flawed little human being
they know themselves to be.

879.text: This is very difficult to overcome.

880.text:
You can't overcome this anxiety
by just doing good work.

885.text:
Because, remember, your anxiety
is that the world thinks

887.text:
that you're better
than you know yourself to be.

890.text:
So every time you get
an award or a promotion,

892.text: or a pat on the back, or praise,

894.text:
it's just deepening that gulf
between the messages

896.text:
that you're getting from the world
and what your self-image is.

901.text:
I think, in some ways,
this can help explain

903.text:
why sometimes, signs
of self-doubt and anxiety

907.text: actually go up after we're praised,

909.text:
and sometimes, they go up
even more so than after we're criticized.

913.text:
Because we spend a hell of a lot of time
trying to impress other people,

916.text:
but when we do impress them, then we worry
that maybe essentially what we've done

921.text:
is just tricked people into thinking
we're something we're not.

925.text:
In some ways, I think, this reinforces
one of the ironies of impostorism.

929.text:
We're not all the kind of people
who're going to make dramatic leaps,

932.text:
and fake our sex, or fake
our religion, or fake our race,

936.text:
but all of us strive
to put a positive face to the world.

940.text:
All of us strive to disguise our flaws
in the eyes of other people.

943.text: We get very good at this.

946.text:
you get more and more sophisticated
at being up to do this.

949.text:
The idea of a true self
or an authentic self

951.text: becomes harder and harder to find.

953.text:
Maybe this is one of the reasons
why we're so intrigued by imposters:

958.text: it's not because we want to be like them

960.text:
but because we worry
that deep down we are like them.

968.text:
Helen Darville got a job
with The Courier-Mail as a columnist,

973.text: but only lasted a couple of weeks.

974.text:
Her second column, as it turned out, was
rampantly plagiarized from the Internet.

980.text:
So she was sacked,
and at that point, she gave up writing.

982.text:
She then enrolled in a law degree
at UQ and graduated,

986.text:
and the last I heard she was working
as a judge's assistant.

990.text: She's now faded out of public life,

992.text:
so I guess, she lives on
really as a memory

994.text:
or as a representation of something,
a symbol of something.

997.text:
Which raises the question
of what does she represent.

1001.text: I think there's two ways to spin this.

1004.text:
On the downside, you could say,
"Here's someone who's a destroyer.

1008.text:
This person bulldozed
through the collective faith of society

1014.text: in order to further her own ambitions."

1017.text:
But I think there's another way
of spinning this.

1020.text:
On the upside, you could say,
"What Helen represents is a reminder

1024.text:
that the world is mysterious,
that the world is full of surfaces,

1028.text:
that many of these surfaces are illusions
and fundamentally, life is a performance

1033.text:
with all the sense of drama, anarchy,
and possibility that this implies.
